text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: When it comes to trials, if it's something like, oh, give this new pill to get we give that to you. We don't bill the insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But that Xtandi, we still have to do what we got to do. Obviously, we're gonna support you in any which way we can. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But yeah, before anything drastic happens, and if you sometimes want to just talk to social work about what is the next step, they can guide you there too. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. Doctor: In the right direction. So I think you know we didn’t get much response to the enzalutamide or that. It sounds, it seems like your cancer may just not be hormonally sensitive at this point. text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example -

text: Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
